channel.title: How to make a c
channel.description: Hey guys. I need help. How do i make it so when i make a new .java, i can use a "c." for client. Any help? I'm using Delta btw.

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @jaruanna jaruanna
item.description:
@jaruanna wrote:

Yea, that was a dumb question to ask. But, i think this is the last question. How do i get the usedonobjectid to transfer into the cooking.java? For some reason i can’t get it to work through the “c.” kind of things. Also, i have another file to handle all packets.

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

jaruanna:

Would the file run automatically, or do i have to declare it somewhere?

You have to implement it anyway you want it.

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

The problem isn’t that it cannot be found, but he’s trying to use a array param when the method requires an integer.

jaruanna:

Yea, i know what it means, t4. But, the problem for the playerhasitem and usedonobjectid, the classes couldn’t find it, although it was in there. Turns out i need to make a method using the array. I can’t find out a way to do it. I can’t put an int and array in the same statement or i get a incomparable types error.

Loop through the array:

for(int j = 0; j < cookOn.length; j++) { //then add statements here. }

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

.\src\server\skills\Cooking.java:19: cannot find symbol
symbol : method playerHasItem(int[])
location: class server.client

.\src\server\skills\Cooking.java:19: cannot find symbol
symbol : variable usedOnObjectID
location: class server.client

not like javac is overly obvious or anything

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c

item.description:
@3lv3n_snip3r wrote:

Try replacing public Cooking
With this one:

public Cooking(Client c) { this.c = c; }

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

[code=java]package server.skills;

import server.*;
import server.Client;
import server.packetHandler.Packets;

public class Cooking {
Client c;

    public Cooking(client client) {
            this.c = client;
    }

    public int cookingRange = 883;
    public int food[] = {317, 321, 327, 331, 335, 338, 341, 345, 349, 353, 
                               359, 363, 371, 377, 383, 389, 395};
    public int cookOn[] = {114, 2728, 2729, 2730, 2731, 2732, 3038, 3769, 
                                   4266, 5499, 11404, 11405, 11406};

    public void cookingNew() {
                    if((c.playerHasItem(food)) && (c.usedOnObjectID == cookOn)) {
            }
    }

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @jaruanna jaruanna
item.description:
@jaruanna wrote:

iz3 legend:

If it’s not packaged you don’t need to declare the class. If it is declare Client c and import Client from its location.

I did that. It still comes up with an error saying it can’t find my methods. Heres my code:

[code]package server.skills;

import server.*;
import server.client;
import server.packetHandler.Packets;
public class Cooking {
client c;

public Cooking(client client) {
this.c = client;
}
public int cookingRange = 883;
public int food[] = {317, 321, 327, 331, 335, 338, 341, 345, 349, 353,
359, 363, 371, 377, 383, 389, 395};
public int cookOn[] = {114, 2728, 2729, 2730, 2731, 2732, 3038, 3769,
4266, 5499, 11404, 11405, 11406};

public void cookingNew() {
if((c.playerHasItem(food)) && (c.usedOnObjectID == cookOn)) {
}
}
}[/code]

And my compiler:

.\src\server\skills\Cooking.java:19: cannot find symbol symbol : method playerHasItem(int[]) location: class server.client if((c.playerHasItem(food)) && (c.usedOnObjectID == cookOn)) { ^ .\src\server\skills\Cooking.java:19: cannot find symbol symbol : variable usedOnObjectID location: class server.client if((c.playerHasItem(food)) && (c.usedOnObjectID == cookOn)) { ^ 2 errors Press any key to continue . . .

Obviously, it can see that it is looking in my client, but it still can’t find my methods…

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a c
item.dc:creator: @iz3_legend iz3 legend
item.description:
@iz3_legend wrote:

If it’s not packaged you don’t need to declare the class. If it is declare Client c and import Client from its location.

Read full topic
